headline: Ohio to spend $10.5 million on ballistics tracing machines
sentences: The money will pay for seven units for the state’s Bureau of Criminal Investigation, including two mobile units, and two stationary units for the Ohio State Highway Patrol.
COLUMBUS, Ohio (AP) — State leaders on Thursday announced plans to spend $10.5 million on additional machines used to trace ballistic evidence from gun crimes.
The matches can indicate whether weapons have been used in multiple shootings and provide investigators with leads to help solve crimes.
The units analyze microscopic markings on bullets and shell casings and compare them to similar evidence from other gun crimes.
The spending increases from nine to 16 the number of Ohio National Integrated Ballistic Information Network units.
